results.title: Divorce and young people
results.creator_credit: Golden Coast Film Productions and Nick Vincent
results.brief_description: Depicts some of the most common fears, conflicts and problems that children face when their parents are going through divorce and demonstrates certain methods of coping with the various emotions that arise. Offers solutions to the problems that children find most difficult to solve in a divorce situation.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Golden Coast Film Productions and Nick Vincent

results.title: Divorce = Li Hun [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Beijing Film Studio and Wang Haowei
results.brief_description: Set in Beijing in the early thirties, “Li Hun” recounts the cultural conficts faced by a well-natured match-maker caught between Chinese tradition and the Western ideas of marriage and family that are beginning to take hold amongst his friends. Adapted from the original work by the famous drama writer Lao She. In Mandarin with English subtitles.

results.title: Divorce = Li Hun
results.creator_credit: Beijing Film Studio, Wang Haowei, Sun Yong and Fu Dehai
results.brief_description:
Big Brother Zhang, a monk, visits Lao Li to discourage him from getting a divorce. Lao Li explains that he has been suffering from depression due to his marriage. Zhang brushes this off as a new-age term that is used without thought. He tells Lao Li to think carefully before making a decision he may later regret.

News spreads that Lao Li has returned to his wife, and they attempt to settle back into their life together. Lao Li has difficulty adjusting to married life again and constantly bickers with his wife. One evening, he reads her a poem about the beauty of solitude and the desire for freedom. She takes offense, thinking the poem is about her.

Meanwhile, Lao Li appears to have feelings for Ma, a young woman who lives in the same housing complex who has been disowned by her family, When Lao Li’s wife finds out, she verbally attacks her in the hallway.

Lao Li’s work colleagues ask to meet his wife. They organise dinner at the local Western Restaurant. Although the restaurant is lavish and high class, Lao Li’s children make a calamitous mess and his wife behaves like a peasant, embarrassing him. Lao Li’s work colleagues laugh at her unrefined behaviour. Lao Li is mortified, believing he is condemned to be laughed at for the rest of his life.

The next day at work, the director of the company pays Lao Li a visit and is impressed by the quality of his work. A colleague invites Lao Li and his wife to dinner at his house, but she is still too embarrassed by the previous night’s proceedings.

That evening, just as Lao Li is about to leave for the dinner by himself, his wife emerges with the children, all nicely dressed, and they all head off together. Much to Lao Li’s pleasure, they behave perfectly.

The next day over lunch, a friend of Lao Li’s tells him of his horrible marriage and subsequent divorce, which has effectively destroyed his life. When Lao Li returns home late that night, his finds his wife has taken up the whole bed, forcing him to sleep on the floor.

The next day is Chinese New Year, and Lao Li encounters Ma in the street. She tells him that they must no longer see each other, so that his wife doesn’t abuse her again. New Year’s Eve celebrations continue while Lao Li sits at home and wallows. A few days later, he witnesses Ma playing with the children in the courtyard.

When Lao Li’s wife discovers that he plans to leave her for Ma, she is devastated, claiming she cannot go on and she wants to die. Humiliated, she calls him heartless. Lao Li resigns from his job. THE END.

Cultural History of the Film:

This film is indicative of a common preoccupation of Chinese Cinema of the time – the relationship between classes.

Lao Li’s class ambition and desire to conceal his family’s peasant roots is incredibly disagreeable, and the way he regards his wife is borderline misogynistic. He appears to detest her for no other reason than her natural peasant inclinations.

It is difficult to determine whether or not the film is critical of Lao Li’s snobbery and pretension. The viewer does, however, sympathise with Lao Li’s wife.
(2 stars - Aleena Glentis; November 2, 2012)

results.title: Divorce
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Family Life Transitions in Marriage”.
Examines the impact of divorce on both children and adults. Uses the case study of a fictional family to show the problems, adjustments, and critical issues involved when couples decide to get a divorce.

results.title: Division of human tumor cells = Teilung von menschlichen tumorzellen
results.creator_credit: Institut für Film und Bild and H. Lettre
results.brief_description: The film shows human tumour cells which have been removed from a patient with carcinoma of the stomach. The cells are contained in the ascitic fluid drawn off from the patient and are observed in this fluid for several hours after removal. A phase-contracts microscope is used with a magnification of 900 times. The conditions for the continued growth and division of the cells are not the most favourable and, in general, only preparations for divisions are observed. However, a normal cell division has been recorded and also a case of tetra-polar division. Silent, with captions in German.

results.title: Division (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mathematics in the Infant/First School”.
The partitive and measure aspects of division are introduced when a group of children discuss two sharing situations and begin to make a wall chart. The program changes direction near the end to show children applying the four operations they have considered, to find as many ways of writing “6” as they can discover.

group_siblings.title: Classroom organisation (TEFC)
group_siblings.creator_credit: Ian Lewis and Drake Educational Associates

results.title: Diving: no place for cowards
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Jacques Bobet and Gary Toole
results.brief_description: The top of a ten-meter diving tower is no place for cowards, according to Jim Lambie, the vociferous coach of two of Canada’s top female divers, Janet Nutter and Linda Cuthbert. In this film we see what goes into making a champion performer and the complete faith and loyalty the athletes have towards Lambie despite his brusque manner. A highlight of the film is the close diving competition at the 1978 Commonwealth Games in Edmonton.

results.title: Diving fundamentals
results.creator_credit: New Official Films and Norman L. Sper
results.brief_description: Opens with a brief history of the sport of diving followed by a demonstration and explanation of the fundamental techniques of diving including the correct way of take-off and lift, entry into the water, proper arm action and body positioning. Commentary by Ken Carpenter. Instruction by Fred Cady.

results.title: Diving
results.brief_description: A very detailed instructional film, explaining the fundamentals of diving, and demonstrating all the most popular championship dives with the aid of slow and stop-motion photography.

results.title: Divine madness
results.brief_description: Shot on location at the Pasadena Civic Auditorium, this live performance by Bette Midler along with “The Harlettes” (Jocelyn Brown, Ula Hedwig and Diva Gray) features some great raunchy comedy material along with some of Bette Midler’s most popular songs including Boogie Woogie Bugle Boy, Chapel of Love, The Rose, Do You Want to Dance.
